description.narrative: The proposed project aims to enhance the capacity of government agencies for improved public service delivery by expanding accessibility to public services, integrating service delivery systems and decentralising their access.

activity-description.narrative: Tashkent is the capital of Uzbekistan

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

comment.narrative: 1.1 The current regulations related to public service delivery needs to be amended in order to better suit the PSC service delivery modality 1.2 Public services delivery processes should apply new and unified Public Services Standards 1.3 No comprehensive assessments conducted aimed to improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed 2.1 Personal of PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies not trained through developed modules (disaggregated by gender) 2.2 Absence of roadmap documents on transfer of front-office operations from relevant government agencies to PSCs 3.1 No new and innovative Public Cervices Centers in project pilot regions are not established and equipped with relevant IT hardware and software 3.2 Absence of regular awareness raising activities/items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc. aimed at broadcasting public services in rural areas 4.1 Absence of dashboard for monitoring activities of PSCs in real time at the MoJ and PSA level 4.2 Absence of institutional arrangements to engage citizens, especially women, in planning local budgets and monitoring their execution in regions

1.1. One (1) regulation amended with the support of the project to better suit the PSC public service delivery modality
1.3. One (1) proposal for improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed to assess quality levels of service delivery
2.1. At least 500 (with at least 175 being women) PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules.
3.1.One (1) PSC established using ergonomic principles equipped with relevant IT hardware and software
3.2. At least 3 awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc.
4.1 Dashboard for monitoring activities of PSCs in real time at the MoJ and PSA level is partially developed and available.
4.2. Institutional arrangements are partially established and are available to engage citizens, especially women, in planning local budgets and monitoring their execution in regions.

1.1. Two (2) regulation amended with the support of the project to better suit the PSC public service delivery modality. Evidence: 1) The project has contributed to the development of the Law of the Republic of Uzbekistan “On Licensing, Permitting and Notification Procedures” (No. ZRU-701 dated 14.07.2021), which also made it possible to digitalize the entire licensing system by introducing a new “License” information system and enabling entrepreneurs to obtain 31 licenses, permits and notifications. Link: https://license.gov.uz/ 2) As a result of the analytical work assessing the current situation in Uzbekistan, as well as the benchmarking of international good practices, a National Public Service Delivery System Development Strategy for 2022-2026 and Round Map was developed as the cornerstone of “citizen-centric” public services. Currently, the document in the format of the draft of the Presidential Decree was sent by the Ministry of Justice to the Cabinet of Ministers and the President’s Administration for consideration. Link: https://u.to/UAL1Gw
1.3. Three proposals for improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed to assess quality levels of service delivery Evidence. 1) set of recommendations and advice to improve mobile service delivery process were shared with PSA based on joint assessment of IPSD & Acceleration Laboratory in two pilot regions (Jizzakh and Syrdarya regions). Report is available here: https://u.to/vQH1Gw. 2) a number of practical recommendations to improve of 2 public services’ regulations related to the nostrification were shared with PSA based on BPR report which conducted in three pilot regions. Link: https://u.to/EQL1Gw 3) set of practical recommendations, advises and guidance to improve 10 most demanded public services’ regulations were shared with PSA based on quality assessment report conducted in five pilot regions. Link: Quality assessment of public service delivery report. Link: https://u.to/IwL1Gw
2.1. 800 (including 245 women) from PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules and capacity building exercises. Evidence: 10 training modules were developed on Leadership, Result based management, HR management, Strategic planning, Stress management and etc.). In total, during the year more than 30 different trainings and capacity building exercises organized by the project and participated by about 800 specialists (245 women) from the front and back offices of public services and regional and district administrations. Link to related data: https://u.to/cwL1Gw and links to some training modules: https://u.to/1Qr1Gw and https://u.to/GAz1Gw
3.1. Seven (7) PSC established using ergonomic principles equipped with relevant IT hardware and software Evidence: The project has already provided practical support to the PSA in the creation of 7 Public Services Centers (Nurafshan city, Bakhmal, Khavast, Dekhkanabad, Shurchi, Bandigon and Khujaily districts). These centers are equipped with the IT equipment, furniture, children’s playgrounds. During the establishment of each center a special attention was paid to the creation of favorable conditions for all categories of the population, including people with the disabilities, that ensured the inclusiveness of pilot public services centers. Volunteers were trained and started to support the PSA/PSCs staff in pilot centers, 7 women advisory groups (WAGs) are fully operating that were established last year with the close cooperation of the NGO Marta (Latvia) started to provide advisory support the rural population. Links to news: https://u.to/qRL1Gw; https://u.to/axD1Gw; https://u.to/3xL1Gw; https://u.to/6xL1Gw
3.2. Four (4) groups (30 pcs.) awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc. Evidence: - 6 infographics were prepared on the new 6 standards of public services. Link: https://u.to/ggL1Gw - 4 posters developed and disseminated: (1) How to receive public services; (2) How to get STIR; (3) The process of online queuing; (4) Public service inventory algorithm. Link: https://u.to/jQL1Gw - special project’s page in the Facebook created and more than 1000 subscribers (Link: https://u.to/ExP1Gw. - 18 TV/radio materials were developed within awareness raising activities. Link: https://u.to/mQL1Gw
4.1 Dashboard for monitoring activities of PSCs in real time at the MoJ and PSA level is partially developed and available. Evidence. The Project provided the Situational Center with IT equipment (computers, monitors, servers, etc.) and a special “Qlick Sense” software for Business Intelligence system. ToR for the Unified Platform of the PSA is developed, and “Qlick Sense” software will be integrated into the new developed Unified platform Link: https://u.to/3Ab1Gw
4.2. Institutional arrangements are partially established and are available to engage citizens, especially women, in planning local budgets and monitoring their execution in regions. Evidence. • 7 Woman advisory groups established under PSC in 7 pilot districts with the help of MARTA Center (Latvia) and Civic initiatives support center, NGO (Uzbekistan). WAGs helped 5362 women and vulnerable people to obtain public services both at Public Service Centers and online through the my.gov.uz website, offered legal and psychological consultations, organized trainings. Link: https://u.to/oQL1Gw • 3 Public advisory councils established under the khokimiyats and Kengashes of people’s deputies in 3 pilot districts (Shurchi, Khavast and Kasansay districts). Link: https://u.to/qgL1Gw New reporting system was introduced in 2 pilot district khokimiyats (Dekhkanabad and Kasansay districts) using Key Performance Indicators (KPI). Link: https://u.to/qgL1Gw • Draft Law on Local government in new edition was prepared and submitted to the Ministry of Justice. It is suggested to separate the position of Khokim (Head of executive authority) from position of Head of Kengashes of people’s deputies (Head of representative authority), wide engagement of citizens, especially women, in planning local budgets and monitoring their execution. Link: https://clck.ru/V5P29 • Since January 2021 new Secretariats of Kengashes of people’s deputies in all districts of Uzbekistan established. Within joint plan of the Senate of the Oliy Majlis and IPSD it was prepared and approved by the Senate’s Resolution a Regulation for newly established Secretariats and Regulations for Kengashes’ Commissions. Link: https://u.to/HhP1Gw.

1.3 At least one (1) proposal for improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed to assess quality levels of service delivery 2.1 At least 10 personnel of PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies trained through developed modules (disaggregated by gender) 3.2 At least 2 awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc. developed.

1.3. One proposal for improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed to assess quality levels of service delivery Evidence. An analytical paper was prepared with organization of a field trip to the pilot regions and using customer survey methods (more than 400 respondents) and submitted to the PSA including: • Assessment of the quality of delivery of 10 most demanded public services and proposals for their improvement; • Proposals on capacity development of the staff of PSA and PSC in the pilot regions including (1) a list of areas of study programs (modules) for distance learning; and (2) a list of desired trainings.
2.1. 40 (including 13 women) PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules (disaggregated by gender) Evidence. In December 9-13, 2019 it was organized a visit of 4 international experts from the Republic of Latvia. During the field trip to the pilot regions (Djizak and Syrdarya regions) there were organized: 2 Round tables for 30 staff (10 of them women) of regional departments of PSA and other organizations which are responsible for public service delivery at regional level; and 2 seminars for 10 staff (3 of them women) of PSC and other organizations which are responsible for public service delivery at district level. The participants were informed on best international practices of organization of work in “one stop shops
3.2. Two awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc. Evidence: • The video about PSA activity in last 2 years has been produced. The film will be shared with national audience including government institutions, local stakeholders, local communities as well as an international audience (on Uzbek and Russian). (https://youtu.be/5oCbsUYqG64; https://youtu.be/pJ6bKb9CHFo) • Project Mapping (animated info graphics) is aimed at attraction foreign donors to the IPSD project activities for the pilot regions, reflecting all project activities, it’s results and outcomes.

2.1. At least 150 PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules (disaggregated by gender) 3.2. At least 4 awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc.

2.1. Total of 1,831 (1,646 men and 185 women) PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules. 3.2. More than 40 PR/news pieces disseminated in local and international media; more than 100 social media posts published; 6 infographics prepared as part of awareness raising items.

1.1. At leasrt three (3) regulation amended with the support of the project to better suit the PSC public service delivery modality 1.2. At least 1 Public Service Standards developed 1.3. At least 3 proposals for improving the quality of public services delivery based on analytical tools developed to assess quality levels of service delivery 2.1. At least 350 (with at least 125 being women) PSA, MoJ and other associated government agencies personnel trained through developed modules (disaggregated by gender) 2.2. At least 1 roadmap document developed on transfer of front-office operations from relevant government agencies to PSCs 3.1.At least three (3) PSC established using ergonomic principles equipped with relevant IT hardware and software 3.2. At least 6 awareness raising items, i.e. TV/radio advertisements, printed material, infographics, videos, etc. 4.1 Developed dashboard for monitoring activities of PSCs in real time at the MoJ and PSA level available 4.2. Established the institutional arrangements to engage citizens, especially women, in planning local budgets and monitoring their execution in regions available
